threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

attributes.magic: Unicode text, UTF-16, little-endian text, with very long lines (32311u), with CRLF line terminators

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Unsigned DLL Loaded by Windows Utility
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects windows utilities loading an unsigned or untrusted DLL.
Adversaries often abuse those programs to proxy execution of malicious code.

match_context.values: @{Hashes=SHA1=42E89B99F8B141FBCDD4F0DEC5D8FFACDD7BD76D,MD5=14B42556CF29965D8AD9F687CFD5ABB9,SHA256=CC302860816DD2BB6ABB2D6973835F81A1504043ED9C5D0F6B04019EEA443A87,IMPHASH=00000000000000000000000000000000; Product=Microsoft\xae .NET Framework; OriginalFileName=System.dll; ImageLoaded=C:\Windows\assembly\NativeImages_v4.0.30319_32\System\ca2cda11f056b8614e0b7a6362c57fe0\System.ni.dll; Description=.NET Framework; SignatureStatus=Unavailable; EventID=7; FileVersion=4.8.9172.0 built by: NET481REL1LAST_C; Signed=false; Image=C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v4.0.30319\InstallUtil.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis: The code initializes two distinct large byte arrays, both of which appear to be embedded .NET assemblies. It then loads the first byte array into memory as a .NET assembly and dynamically retrieves a method named "Run" from a class identified as "ClassLibrary1.Class1" within this loaded assembly. Separately, it constructs a string by concatenating the system path to `installutil.exe` with another long string that contains multiple paths, including what appear to be PowerShell script file names. Finally, it invokes the "Run" method, passing the concatenated string (likely as a command or argument), the second byte array (presumably another embedded assembly), and a boolean value `true` as arguments. The overall logic points to an attempt to execute embedded payloads and leverage a legitimate Windows utility for execution.
